>
> The JUNGLE as everyone pretty much called it was huge! Thousands of
>=
 acres all around with trees reaching up over one hundred feet into the
> a=
ir like tall green spires reaching ever higher into the skies,
> supported =
by thick powerful trunks and supporting power of the
> neighboring trees.
>=
 
> At first travel was easy as WHEELIE followed a trail of devastation
> a=
nd deforestation. It was as if a stampede of hundreds of large
> animals fl=
ed the jungle, crashing into trees and stripping foliage as
> they traveled=
. The result of which was a wide open and relatively
> smooth open path of =
travel several miles into the immense wooded area.
> But as time passed and=
 the miles built upon themselves the impact of
> the animal's passing becom=
e less and less noticeable, the area itself
> becoming ever darker from the=
 trees high over head and the thick
> growth of brush. The ground was becom=
ing more and more uneven as tree
> roots grew into the pathway. What was on=
ce a brightly lit area was now
> much darker, looking like deep evening, ev=
en though the noonday sun
> burned brightly over head, blocked by thge lush=
 canopy of trees, that
> only occasionally let in shafts of sunlight light =
to break open the
> growing darkness.
> 
> Even the smell of things was beg=
inning to change. The earth smell of
> decomposing leaves and animal waste =
could be smelled. Not necessarily
> a bad smell, but one that reminded you =
of the richness of the soil
> that was being moved across.
> 
> WHEELIE emp=
loying all the skills and experience at his disposal was
> able to make his=
 way in through the uneven and sometimes broken
> ground, the jungle floor =
was perhaps among the most inhospitable to
> wheeled vehicles that most of =
the Earth at this time had to offer.
> Lattice works of roots and foliage g=
ot caught in tires, the brush
> having the annoying habit of blocking sight=
 and hiding nasty ravines
> and holes and twisted turns. Branches and roots=
 jutted out at strange
> angles threatening to stab into more sensative and=
 vulnerable
> undersides and tires.
> 
> The sounds of the jungle was all a=
round WHEELIE, animals chattered at
> him from the ground, as others hangin=
g high in the trees looked down
> at the strange orange conveyance that dar=
ed travel through demesne.
> There were signs of life all around him - The =
catcalls of other
> animals, even a few roars in the distance of large pred=
atory beasts.
> Trees and branches moved strangely as if something indiscer=
nible was
> moving among them even if the author of the movement could not =
itself
> be readily seen.
> 
> Then there was the eerie feeling of being wa=
tched. It was a feeling
> that settled upon someone slowly at first. Perhap=
s a sound that didn't
> repeat itself or a movement than stopped when you d=
id. Maybe it was
> just a gut feeling that somewhere out in the density of =
the foliage,
> in the darkest shadows something was out there, and it was p=
eering at
> you, considering you.
> 
> It was into this maze of tree and wo=
od, sounds and smells that WHEELIE
> was driving, covered in muck and weavi=
ng past trees that were as large
> around as he was long. And yet despite a=
ll of that, there was a
> strange sort of barely discernable path that led =
further and further
> into the jungle interior, meandering at times and yet=
 always present.
> .
> 
> OOC: For anyone that wants to fly in, you will fi=
nd that you cannot
> see the jungle floor, at least the section that Wheeli=
e is in. You can
> see the devastation that he followed in, but after a few=
 miles it
> fades and the jungle growth takes over. Any smells or sounds he=
 would
> give off would be muffled by the dense foliage and the ambient sou=
nds
> and smells of the jungle. In short he would be nearly impossible to
>=
 find anyone on the forest floor from the air unless you find one of
> the =
infrequent clearings. If you need a more aerial description of the
> place =
I can describe that in a different post. Just let me know

<NEW - WHEELI=
E>

WHEELIE tracked over the traces of destruction.  He kept his communicat=
or on, but set to receive only rather than broadcast.  But for those back a=
t base, he could probably be tracked over by his signal as it went deeper i=
nto the jungle, but his intenrla comm was set on minimal power.

As he trac=
ked the traces of destruction, and then going back into the underbrush as i=
t petered out, caked over in mud to try and help minimize his signal, his b=
right orange coloration muted to the point he would not stand out as much.
=

As the destruction petered out, WHEELIE would think it was recent, but it =
only went out to this area, fresh and then had ended for whatever point.  W=
hile WHEELIE was not a tracker, nor did he have enhanced senses, he did hav=
e experience with observation.  So, to these skills he would try and learn =
to note that which was foreign to the jungle.  To attempt to locate as best=
 he could the signs of larger beasts which were not native to the area and =
woudl be Cybertronian beast modes that were not natural, heavier and bulkie=
r.  IF he could, he would attempt to start trailing them by foot.  Failing =
the ability to locate any, he would continue moving in the general trail th=
at the direction had last pointed in, going slowly and attempting to attune=
 himself to the background.

WHEELIE sened within his spark that something =
was watching him, someone was after him.  But he could not locate it aginst=
 the heavy background of the underbrush.  He could not tell whether it was =
the animal life irritated at the invasion fo their territory, a hidden beas=
t waiting to pounce, or a Cybertronian more adept at tracking than he was s=
taying hidden and stealthed and following him.  Or merely his own hesitatio=
n and unfamiliarity with the area and his awareness of his own lack of awar=
eness at the region speaking to him to keep him on his wheels.

Not having =
a more explicit idea fo what was going on, Wheelie gingerly continued, one =
step at a time, going slowly and warily.  Keeping his energon slingshot in =
a subspace pocket but fully charged, so should it come over to combat he co=
uld immediately whip it out to engage someone, and keeping enough space bet=
ween himself and the underbrush if he was ambushed he would have some room =
to react.
